cards.title: Olympics’ Eurosport carve-up will have one simple result: fewer viewers
cards.rawTitle: Olympics’ Eurosport carve-up will have one simple result: fewer viewers

item.title: Olympics’ Eurosport carve-up will have one simple result: fewer viewers
item.trailText: The IOC’s decision to put the Games behind a paywall will deprive those who can’t pay or the previously uninitiated who might be inspired by what they see
item.standFirst: The IOC’s decision to put the Games behind a paywall will deprive those who can’t pay or the previously uninitiated who might be inspired by what they see
item.body:
I am perplexed by the International Olympic Committee’s failure to rush out the announcement that it is taking the Olympics to pay TV at 6.31am on the morning of 27 May. That, you may recall, was a few minutes into the raid on the hotel lair of its kissing cousin, Fifa, and the subsequent full spectrum dominance of that story would have been the perfect place to bury the news.

Then again, why should the custodians of the Olympic flame have denied themselves the post-satirical laugh of being able to dispense moral advice to their fellow international governing body? “[Fifa] is a complete and utter mess – it may be too late,” intoned the IOC, which was last seen in the VIP seats as Vladimir Putin actually invaded a country during his Winter Games.

Either way, the IOC picked this week to reveal it has ended its rights arrangement with a group of European public service broadcasters and sold them to Eurosport, a landmark action that can be boiled down to one simple result: far fewer people will watch the Olympics. It’s like the motto goes: Citius, Altius, Pay-for-us.

With this decision, the Olympic movement has cast in its lot with the parcelling and packaging of sport, and if that seems to you the very opposite of what it should be about, rest assured you’re not looking at it right. The way to develop sport is to free it from the possibility of being sampled by kids whose parents don’t subscribe, kids whose parents can’t afford to subscribe, kids now spared the inspiration of experiencing things to which they would otherwise not be exposed.

Related: Despite losing control of rights to the Olympics, all is not lost for the BBC

According to the IOC president Thomas Bach, the £992m deal shows “a new broader approach to Olympic broadcasting”. It certainly shows a broader definition to the term “broad”. In fact, on these terms broad now becomes one of those words that can also means their opposite – like cleave, or trim. In 2012 the BBC showed 2,500 hours of the Olympics. Under the new deal, 200 hours will be offered on free to air. Broadly speaking, this is the new broad.

And really, what could possibly go wrong? Look what this kind of model has done to cricket. Cricket is now watched by people who are already cricket fans, and by the children of bill-paying cricket fans. Unless their parents subscribe, kids can’t just turn on the cricket these days – but it is impossible to behold the giant SkyPad and not think it was all worth it.

Even so, that the Olympic movement should have gone down this route feels like a particularly black form of self-parody. More than any other event, the Olympics is about the competitors, their journeys, their backstories, their struggles to compete in sports with minimal remuneration. Placing these behind a paywall radically diminishes their reach.

As far as the viewership goes, meanwhile, it’s not just about convincing those who love rowing – it’s about entrancing those who have never got in a boat but might be inspired.

You would have more luck convincing the majority of Olympic viewers to subscribe to Crochet Weekly than an Olympics channel in the run-up to any Games. Yet the minute it starts, something magical always happens. People who don’t even usually watch sport become obsessive about archery or handball. Watching the curling becomes a collective experience as bonkers as it is beautiful – and its being free to air is the sine qua non of that.

Alas, this is not in line with the drive of modern sport broadcasting. Sports are now sold as “have to have”, whereas in the past their universal availability cast them as “I might just experience”. The possibility of seeing something for yourself and being able to get into it without recourse to a bill-payer is vanishing. Thus the parcelling of sport becomes another way to stratify society, to make children the products of their parents’ pockets.

When the pay-TV rights holders have finished carving payment packages up into distinct sports, as the direction of travel indicates will effectively happen, how easy will it be to be part of different communities – to love cricket and football, to pony up for the Premier League and still have enough left over for the cricket or the Olympics or whatever in the past might have freely taken your fancy? The near extinction of the working-class actor is much commented on; perhaps the working-class cricket watcher will be next to go.

Unless you have the funds for all of it, you will be a football household, or a cricket household, or an athletics household (and yup, there’ll be loads of athletics households). Many will be households where watching sport is not possible.

Meanwhile, for all the IOC waffle about how the money will benefit the athletes, only the terminally optimistic will not wonder how quickly the broadcasting tail will wag the dog, and less watchable sports will find themselves the poor relation to those deemed more bankable.

Experience tells us the IOC will roll over, given its tendency always to ally naturally with the powerful at the expense of the powerless – by which we mean the athletes. Bach was punitively opposed to athletes making protests at Sochi, for instance, but apparently intensely relaxed by Putin using the entire event for political purposes.

“Why did I restore the Olympic Games?” Pierre de Coubertin inquired rhetorically. “To ennoble and strengthen sports, to ensure their independence and duration, and thus to enable them better to fulfil the educational role incumbent on them in the modern world.” A vision just made for the slogan: “ONLY ON EUROSPORT”.

cards.title: AFL / Gold Coast Suns drug accusations won't change 'three strikes' policy
cards.rawTitle: Gold Coast Suns drug accusations won't change 'three strikes' policy

item.title: Gold Coast Suns drug accusations won't change AFL's 'three strikes' policy
item.trailText: The AFL won’t expedite a review of its “three strikes” illicit drugs policy in light of explosive allegations of drug use at expansion club Gold Coast
item.standFirst: • AFL chief executive Gillon McLachlan quashes talk of a drugs policy review
item.body:
The AFL won’t expedite a review of its “three strikes” illicit drugs policy in light of explosive allegations of drug use at expansion club Gold Coast.

Photos of Suns forward Harley Bennell appearing to prepare drugs on a March 2013 pre-season club trip to Launceston have been widely circulated, adding a dramatic new dimension to the club’s woes.

But AFL chief executive Gillon McLachlan said he had full faith in the club’s ability to navigate the crisis.

He added the Suns should not be seen as the only AFL club - or part of society - grappling with the issue.

“They’re the same challenges that many, potentially all, of our clubs have faced to a greater or lesser extent,” he told reporters on Thursday.

“Whether they’re 140-years-old or 20-years old, everyone has (challenges) and it’s how you respond to them which is ultimately the proof of where this club goes.

“These stories of start-up clubs are not linear journeys, they have lumps and swings and roundabouts.”

The AFL supremo said the league’s focus was ensuring the wellbeing of Bennell, who has been stood down by the Suns for Saturday’s match with North Melbourne.

McLachlan suggested placing compromising photos of the star forward on the front page of News Corp papers was reckless.

“It increases the vulnerability of a young man who we know has had significant challenges,” he said.

“He’s had an incredibly tough background.

“It means more than ever, his welfare is incredibly important and our focus.

“The club have been working closely with Harley for a couple of years ... and are ensuring he has the right people around him to deal with today and to deal with his challenges ongoing.”

The AFL’s challenge now is to help the expansion club through its illicit drugs problems.

Former player Karmichael Hunt’s revelations to the Queensland Crime and Corruption Commission on the weekend sparked claims of a drug-fuelled culture at the Suns.

It’s brought into sharp light the AFL’s “three strikes” policy, which deals with recreational and not performance enhancing drug use amongst players.

Having announced a review of the policy in March, McLachlan he wouldn’t be rushing in a new policy and overriding months of careful considerations.

“Our policy was right 10 years ago but I’m not sure that it is going forward, and we’ve been reviewing it for many weeks and we’ll have a new policy in place for the start of the off season,” he said.

“It’s an illustration today, it’s the same issue, it’s just quite graphic and I guess unprecedented.

“Today I don’t think changes anything. We’re aware of the challenges, we called them out many months ago.”

McLachlan again conceded the policy did need changing.

“The policy has to balance up the rights of the players and their welfare ... and the responsibilities and accountabilities to our industry, to our clubs and our supporters,” he said.

“We think the policy has room for improvement to get a greater level of accountability into the system.

“It probably needs to be that every strike has an action or an accountability point but that doesn’t mean it’s a zero tolerance. It’s a delicate balance.”

cards.title: Rugby league / Wakefield end run of 16 defeats with win against Hull
cards.rawTitle: Wakefield end run of 16 defeats with win against Hull

item.title: Wakefield end run of 16 defeats with win against Hull
item.trailText: Wakefield’s victory saw Jacob Miller, Richard Owen, Joe Arundel and Matt Ryan score tries, with Miller adding five goals
item.standFirst:
• Wakefield 26-16 Hull
• Jacob Miller, Richard Owen, Joe Arundel and Matty Ryan score tries
item.body:
Brian Smith watched Wakefield end their 16-match losing run in Super League with a fine fightback against Hull – and then blamed himself for their woeful start. It looked to be a familiar tale for the bottom club as they fell 16-0 behind after conceding tries to Kirk Yeaman, Jordan Rankin and Liam Watts inside the first 17 minutes.

But they hit back with four unanswered tries of their own through Jacob Miller, Richard Owen, Joe Arundel and Matty Ryan to win 26-16, their first league success since February.

“There is a lot of relief in there,” said Smith, who was in charge of his third match. “There’s been a lot of people working for that, chiseling away and trying to get over the hump for 16 games.

“ The players have been working hard to get there and they had to work the hardest way, coming from 16-0 down but they did it well in the end.

We were very disappointing in those early minutes and I think I’ve got to look at myself and what I’m doing there because that’s three really sluggish starts in a row.”

“So I need to review it with Stuey [Dickens] and Lee [Gilmour] and the other staff to see if we can work out a different way to start a game because that is the hardest way to play football. For a team that’s down on confidence to concede tries as softly as we did and then come back is like running uphill the whole game.”

Former New Zealand international full-back Kevin Locke, one of three debutants, was named the sponsors’ man of the match but he agreed with his coach that the award flattered him.

Locke, who joined the Wildcats on a short-term deal after securing a release from his unhappy time at Salford, struggled at times in his first match for two months but played a key role in two of Wakefield’s tries.

Smith added: “I spoke to Kev after the game and told him they had named him man of the match and he said ’wait until I’m fit’.

“He had some nice touches but Kevin was well off his game at times tonight and understandably so.

“It’s been a terribly emotional time for him, it’s been a big drain on him but he’s got a smile back on his face. Hopefully we can keep him in a really positive environment and he can continue to improve his game.

“His knee is not his problem it’s just general fitness and sharpness.”

While Wakefield remain rooted to the foot of the table, still seven points adrift of Salford, they will head for the run-in in buoyant mood, starting with a return game against Hull at the KC Stadium on Sunday.

That is now a must-win fixture for Hull, who missed the chance to climb out of the bottom four, just a week after crashing out of the Challenge Cup in dismal fashion.

“I’m deflated hugely,” Hull coach Lee Radford said. “We had highlighted the importance of this fixture and what a difficult this place is to come to. Our record at this ground is terrible. It’s always a dogfight here and I expected to scrape it if we were going to get a result.

“But after that 15-minute period we didn’t give ourselves a chance to get any momentum back. Our completion rate was 60 per cent again. That’s two weeks on the spin now and that’s not good enough.

“Our energy looked fine at the start but a couple of calls went against us, a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes and back-to-back penalties and before you know it the game has gone.”

Hull also had prop Mickey Paea placed on report for a tackle that left former team-mate Danny Washbrook concussed but Radford does not expect any repercussions.

“He has got nothing whatsoever to worry about, there was nothing in it,” Radford said. “He’s not gone over the horizontal and Washy hurt his head on the floor.”

cards.title: Rugby union / Giteau and Mitchell named in Wallabies' Championship squad
cards.rawTitle: Giteau and Mitchell named in Wallabies' Championship squad

item.title: Giteau, Mitchell named in Wallabies' Rugby Championship squad
item.trailText: France-based Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell have been included in Australia’s squad for the start of the Rugby Championship while George Smith and James O’Connor are notable omissions
item.standFirst:
• Four uncapped players named in 40-man squad
  • No place on Michael Cheika’s list for James O’Connor or George Smith
item.body:
France-based Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell have been included in Australia’s squad for the start of the Rugby Championship while Karmichael Hunt and James O’Connor are notable omissions.

After a standout season with the Waratahs, Fiji-born Taqele Naiyaravoro is one of four uncapped players named in the 40-man Wallabies squad on Thursday.

With a view to the World Cup later this year, Wallabies coach Michael Cheika opted to announce an extended squad only for the opening game of the Rugby Championship against South Africa in Brisbane on July 18.

Veteran props Benn Robinson and Ben Alexander were left out, leading to a recall for Queensland front-rower Greg Holmes and a call-up for New Zealand-raised Rebels prop Toby Smith.

Hunt and O’Connor, who both struggled with injury and form during the Super Rugby season but have utility value, were also omitted but their Reds teammates Quade Cooper and powerful inside centre Samu Kerevi got the nod.

Kerevi, winger Naiyaravoro, Smith and Brumbies lock Rory Arnold are the four uncapped players named.

While Toulon teammates Giteau and Mitchell won recalls, back-rower George Smith - who was the other overseas-based player available due to changes in the eligibility rules - wasn’t named even though he’s been in impressive form for Lyon in France.

The Australian Rugby Union eased eligibility rules earlier this year, allowing overseas-based players who have 60 Test caps and held a contract with Australian rugby for at least seven years to be picked.

Scott Higginbotham and Sam Carter return after missing last season’s spring tour due to injury, while Waratahs skipper David Dennis also gets the chance to add to his 18 Wallabies Tests after missing most of 2014 with a knee injury.

Wallabies squad:

Rory Arnold, Adam Ashley-Cooper, Kurtley Beale, Quade Cooper, Dave Dennis, James Hanson, Scott Fardy, Tetera Faulkner, Israel Folau, Bernard Foley, Will Genia, Matt Giteau, Scott Higginbotham, Greg Holmes, Michael Hooper, Rob Horne, James Horwill, Samu Kerevi, Sekope Kepu, Tevita Kuridrani, Christian Leali’ifano, Stephen Moore, Drew Mitchell, Wycliff Palu, Ben McCalman, Sean McMahon, Dean Mumm, Taqele Naiyaravoro, Nick Phipps, David Pocock, Tatafu Polota-Nau, Scott Sio, Rob Simmons, Will Skelton, James Slipper, Toby Smith, Henry Speight, Matt Toomua, Joe Tomane, Nic White.

headerImage.caption: Matt Giteau returns to the international fold, but there’s no space in Michael Cheika’s extended Wallabies squad for James O’Connor, George Smith or Karmichael Hunt. Photograph: Andrew Brownbill/AP

cards.title: Rugby World Cup 2015 / Key England games to be refereed by French officials
cards.rawTitle: Key England games to be refereed by French officials

item.title: Rugby World Cup: Key England games to be refereed by French officials
item.trailText: England’s key World Cup pool games against Wales and Australia will both be refereed by French officials, World Rugby has announced
item.standFirst:
• Appointments for the tournament’s pool games announced
• England and Fiji open event at Twickenham on 18 September
item.body:
England’s key World Cup pool games against Wales and Australia will both be refereed by French officials, it has been revealed, after referee appointments for the tournament’s pool games were announced by World Rugby.

England and Fiji kick off the tournament at Twickenham on 18 September, when South African official Jaco Peyper will be at the helm, while Jerome Garces has been handed the England versus Wales clash eight days later.

And Garces’ fellow Frenchman Romain Poite will control England’s Twickenham appointment with Australia in early October. Only two teams qualify from each group, meaning that either England, Wales or Australia are set to miss out on a quarter-final place.

Wales’s final group game against Australia at Twickenham has been awarded to top South African referee Craig Joubert, while England’s Wayne Barnes will be in the middle when New Zealand launch their world title defence against Argentina on 20 September.

Welshman Nigel Owens, regarded by many pundits as the world’s leading rugby union referee, has been appointed to Scotland versus South Africa and Ireland versus France.

Referee appointments for the World Cup knockout phase will be made after the pool fixtures.

cards.title: AFL / Suns: Players' health 'absolute priority' after Hunt drug allegations
cards.rawTitle: Suns: Players' health 'absolute priority' after Hunt drug allegations

item.title: Suns: Players' health 'absolute priority' after Karmicheal Hunt drug allegations
item.trailText: Gold Coast say their immediate concern is ensuring the welfare of player Harley Bennell after pictures of the young gun apparently taking illicit drugs were shown in the media
item.standFirst: • AFL club Gold Coast Suns deal with fallout from Hunt allegations
item.body:
Gold Coast say their immediate concern is ensuring the welfare of player Harley Bennell after pictures of the young gun apparently taking illicit drugs were displayed across the media.

Images taken at a Launceston Hotel before the start of the 2013 season show Bennell with lines of white powder, allegedly speed.

The publication of the photos comes just a day after Queensland’s Crime and Corruption Commission (QCCC) announced it didn’t have sufficient evidence to warrant further arrests of any professional sportsmen in relation to the investigation of a cocaine trafficking syndicate in south-east Queensland.

Former Sun Karmichael Hunt has reportedly named up to 12 of his ex-AFL teammates for allegedly taking cocaine during various end-of-season functions as part of a statement given to police following his own conviction on cocaine possession charges.

In a statement, the QCCC said it remained possible further charges could be laid if new evidence comes to hand.

Bennell, the No.2 pick in the 2010 draft, is a former flatmate of Hunt’s and the Suns praised the ex-rugby league star’s influence over his younger teammate last year when Hunt’s time at the Suns came to an end.

In a brief statement, a spokesman for the Suns says the club’s main priority is the player’s welfare.

"We can’t underestimate the toll this could have and has had on his wellbeing," the spokesman said.

"That remains our absolute focus at this time."

The AFL Players’ Association (AFLPA) says it is addressing the matter along with the Suns and the AFL.

"With respect to the current issue, we have been working closely with the player involved to provide him with as much support as possible," AFLPA chief executive Paul Marsh said.

"Our absolute priority is the health and wellbeing of our players and we have been working hard to ensure appropriate support and wellbeing networks are in place for all players who require them."

Marsh also defended the code’s illicit-drug policy, saying it had done more good for players than harm.

"Illicit-drug usage amongst AFL players is not a new issue," he said.

"We know through testing that it exists at a level, albeit much lower than that of those in society of the same age group as AFL players.

"The AFL’s Illicit-Drug Policy was introduced to educate, deter but also support any players using illicit drugs. The facts are that this policy has worked over its 10-year history with a significant decrease in the percentage of players testing positive to illicit drug usage."

AFL head of corporate affairs Elizabeth Lurkin told Newscorp Australia both the league and the players’ association were working with clubs to review and strengthen the illicit-drugs policy.
